column6: Scientific approach to understanding social interaction, institutions and organization.
Fundamental study of sociological analysis designed to provide awareness of theoretical and methodological concepts necessary in developing sociological perspective.

An introduction to the cultural and structural factors creating and sustaining educational, economic and political inequality by race, ethnicity, gender, class and sexual orientation with an emphasis on issues of poverty and immigration.

Contemporary American and global social problems and issues are analyzed from sociological perspectives. Several cases are used to illustrate the emergence, development and decline of problems in social context.

Exploration of the sociological nature of families across the lifespan, focusing on structure, diversity and life course processes such as dating, mate selection, cohabitation, marriage, parenthood, divorce, remarriage, singlehood, widowhood, parent-child interactions, sexual orientation, inequality and difference.
Individual research experience in sociology.

column4: SOC 12050, junior standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: Readings and/or research supervised by member of sociology faculty.
Survey of methods and techniques of research; research design and data gathering instruments; qualitative and quantitative analysis.
The use of quantitative methods in the analysis of data from social research. Emphasis on descriptive statistics.
Analysis of sociological data utilizing statistical and electronic data processing tools. Corequisite: SOC 32220.
Foundations of social psychology; process of socialization; development of social and personal identities; small group and collective behavior; theories of deviance.
Consideration of world of work across time and cultures with special emphasis on American society. Impact of work on individuals and other social institutions.
Social history of the American family. Examination of how race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, class, gender and age contribute to variation in the experience and structure of family life in the U.S.
Examination of sexual identities, societal attitudes and debates, and differences of gender, race, age and class in gay/lesbian communities, using both social movements and life span perspectives.
Study of such major American minorities as blacks, American Indians, Spanish-speaking Americans and American Jews.

Sociological analysis of stratification and inequality in societies, and the social structures that produce and maintain them. Particular emphasis on the intersections of race, class and gender in American society.
Determinants and consequences of population change, with emphasis on mortality, fertility and migration.
Examination of the history and development of urban areas, urban sociological theories and selected topics such as poverty, immigration, race relations and urban planning.

Overview of classical and contemporary theories and perspectives on the nature, causes and societal management of deviant behavior. Application of theories and perspectives to modern and historical social problems, methods of punishment and policy trends in social control.

Theoretical perspectives and research in human death and dying. Emphasis on applied concerns in medical and helping professions. Topics include social death, death as taboo, medicalization and rationalization of death and dying and disenfranchised grief.

column4: Junior standing; and sociology (SOC) major and 2.50 grade point average and special approval.
column6: Application of sociological knowledge in the work setting. Assist professionals in sites including social services hospitals industry and government.
Concentrates on professional or disciplinary concerns. Specific content to vary according to needs of client groups. S u/graded.
Offered irregularly when unusual resources and/or opportunities permit. Topic announced when scheduled. Repeatable for a total of 12 hours for majors.
An examination of classical, modern and postmodern approaches to social theory.

column4: SOC 32210 or SOC 32220; and special approval.
column6: Emphasis on organizing, analyzing and interpreting actual sociological research data making use of basic descriptive and inferential statistics and computer programs.
An examination of the institutions, institutional linkages and social processes that contribute to change and stability of traditional gender roles and the consequences of changes.
Investigation of various movements for social change. Examines the origins, developmental characteristics and the purposes of classic and contemporary movements.

Examines theories and research on the origin and behavioral consequences of identities, self-concept and self-esteem; also examines the relationships between identities and emotions and between self-concept and mental health.

How socio-historical circumstances shape the perception and experience of childhood as a distinct life stage. The process of childhood socialization in Western societies particularly the U.S. An exploration of the distinct role of socializing agents-parents and siblings, Department, peers and media.

Consideration of the social, cultural and historical forces that shape the experience of this period of the life cycle. Includes examination of gender, class, and race differences in adolescence the significance of youth movements with an emphasis on music as a dominant expression of youth culture.
Sociological examination of economic stratification; focuses on the translation of class into power via politics, education and collective struggle.
Social context of religious ideologies and structures with special reference to religion in America.

A sociology of mental health and illness; focuses on how social factors influence and are influenced by mental health status; topics include definition and measurement, social distribution, social control of mental illness, societal reaction and media coverage.

column2: SOCIOLOGY OF HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE
column6: Sociological analysis of health and illness behavior, utilization of health care professions and the organizational community and societal systems which deal with health and illness.
Analysis of structure and functioning of complex organizations in their cultural context.
Sociological principles underlying racial and ethnic relations in the United States; emphasis on social factors of prejudice, discrimination and assimilation affecting all groups.
Cultural variability with respect to courtship, family relationships, child rearing and other patterns in primitive and literate societies.
Sociological analysis of theories, research and social policy concerning family violence, child abuse and neglect, spouse abuse, elderly abuse, marital rape, sexual abuse of children.

Examines the particular role of the practitioner unique to gerontology using case study, cross-cultural comparisons and research analysis. Recommended for students with a major or minor in gerontology.
Analysis of demographic, sociological and socio-psychological dimensions of aging.
Examines conceptualizations for and evidence concerning the effects of social structure on various dimensions of individual lives.

Theoretical perspectives and research in human death and dying. Emphasis on applied concerns in medical and helping professions. Topics include social death, death as taboo, medicalization and rationalization of death and dying, and disenfranchised grief.
An examination of classical, modern and post-modern approaches to social theory.
An examination of the institutions, institutional linkages and social processes that contribute to change and stability of traditional gender roles and the consequences of changes.
Investigation of various movements for social change. Examines the origins developmental characteristics and the purposes of classic and contemporary movements.

How socio-historical circumstances shape the perception and experience of childhood as a distinct life stage. The process of childhood socialization in Western societies particularly the U.S. An exploration of the distinct role of socializing agents- parents and siblings, Department, peers and media.

Consideration of the social, cultural and historical forces that shape the experience of this period of the life cycle. Includes examination of gender, class and race differences in adolescence, the significance of youth movements with an emphasis on music as a dominant expression of youth culture.
Sociological examination of economic stratification in the United States; focuses on the translation of class into power via politics, education and collective struggle.
Social context of religions and their ideologies and structures with special reference to religion in America.

column2: SOCIOLOGY OF HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE
column6: Sociological analysis of health and illness behavior, utilization of health care, professions, and the organizational, community, and societal systems that deal with health and illness.
Analysis of structure and functioning of complex organizations in their cultural context.
Sociological principles underlying racial and ethnic relations in the United States; emphasis on social factors of prejudice, discrimination and assimilation affecting all groups.
Sociological analysis of theories, research and social policy concerning family violence, child abuse and neglect, spouse abuse, elderly abuse, marital rape, sexual abuse of children.
Examines the particular role of the practitioner unique to gerontology using case study, cross- cultural comparisons and research analysis.
Analysis of demographic, sociological and socio psychological dimensions of aging.

column2: PROFESSIONAL AND ETHICAL ISSUES IN SOCIOLOGY
column6: Introduction to professional and ethical issues in the field of sociology including the logic of inquiry, developing effective approaches to independent learning and research, the human subjects review process and plagiarism. Akron 3850:628.
Concentrates on professional or disciplinary concerns. Specific content to vary according to needs of client groups.

column4: SOC 4/52126 and graduate standing in sociology.
column6: An examination of the contributions by pre-1930 social thinkers to contemporary sociological theory. Akron 3850:722.

column4: SOC 62100 or SOC 72100; and graduate standing in sociology.
column6: Covers major contemporary theories and theorists. Emphasis on functionalism, conflict, exchange, interactionism and systems theory. Neofunctionalism, neo-Marxism, structuration theory and other recent trends are treated. Akron 3850:723.

column4: Graduate standing in sociology and special approval.
column6: Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.

Introduction to the use of quantitative research methods for analyzing sociological issues. Includes instruction on each step in the process of empirically verifying a theoretical question, from conceptualization to analysis. Akron 3850:603.
Seminar on innovations in research methods. Akron 3850: 708.

column4: SOC 32220 and graduate standing in sociology.
column6: Advanced multivariate techniques and methodological problems in the analysis of sociological data. Topics include non-experimental causal models and path analysis. Akron 3850:706.

column4: SOC 6/72217 and graduate standing in sociology.
column6: Critical examination of data analytic techniques having particular relevance to research problems in sociology, with particular emphasis on multi-variate inferential statistics. Akron 3850:709.
Study of qualitative methods including interviewing, observation, use of personal documents, archival data and special problems of recording and analyzing qualitative data. Akron 3850:714.
An in-depth study of the design and administration of social surveys. Akron 3850:711.

column4: SOC 62199; and graduate standing in sociology; and special approval.
column6: Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
A general study of the field of medical sociology with special emphasis on analysis of health and health care in the contemporary urban United States. Akron 3850:656.

column2: SOCIOLOGY OF MENTAL HEALTH AND MENTAL DISORDERS
column6: Sociological examination of the social processes that affect mental health, frame cultural ideas of normality and illness, and define clinical pathology. Akron 3850: 728.
Race, social class and gender differences in physical and mental health status, help seeking behavior and health care. Race, class and gender stratification of health care workers. Akron 3850:726.

Examination of social psychological theory and research, both classic and contemporary. Provides student with background and working knowledge of social psychological aspects of social phenomena. Akron 3850: 631.

Examination of contemporary theory and research on linkages between personality and society. Emphasis will be on the dynamics of those linkages and their effects on both individuals and social structures. Akron 3850:634.

An introduction to the methods, theories and topics of social epidemiology SOC 62434 SOCIOLOGY OF COMMUNICATION This course provides a general survey of the micro aspects of social communication. The concentration is on the sociolinguistic orientation to analysis of human communication. Akron 3850: 635.
A sociological perspective is employed to analyze and understand the production, distribution and utilization of socially created sentiments and emotions.
Examination of work as behavioral phenomenon in human societies; contrasts with non-work and leisure significance of occupations, professions and work types in organization of work. Akron 3850:649.
Analysis of actual and theoretical patterns of family systems; current research in family in relation to theories of family and theories of social systems. Akron 3850:677.
An overview of social inequalities -definitions, causes, identities, structures and consequences. The focus is on social class with attention to intersecting dimensions of inequality. Akron 3850:646.

Examination of theories and research on gender origins, characteristics and changes. Emphasizes recent empirical research on gender role patterns and processes in various industrial societies. Akron 3850:639.

Examination of nature, types and controls of deviance; analysis of conceptual levels, theoretical contributions, processes in social labeling and self-labeling, case studies, social consequences and problems. Akron 3850: 663.
An in-depth study of the theories, models, research approaches and substantive areas that constitute the sociology of race and ethnicity. Akron 3850:651.
Impact of aging upon individuals and society. Reactions of individuals and society to aging. Akron 3850:678.

column4: Graduate standing in sociology and special approval.
column6: Student negotiated project in specific human service setting for practitioner; program designing, research in service training, writing a grant proposal.
Preparation for college teaching. Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward master's degree requirements (with departmental approval). Hours do not count toward the doctoral degree. Akron 3850:700.
Offered irregularly when unusual resources and/or opportunities permit. Topic will be announced when scheduled.

column4: graduate standing and sociology (SOC) major and special approval.
column6: Intensive pursuit of a subject matter beyond normal course coverage with the possibility of associated research. Only 3 credits count toward the Master's degree.

column4: graduate standing and sociology (SOC) major and special approval.
column6: Pursuit of research interests which can include the student's project and/or a faculty member's project. Only 2 credits count toward the Master's degree.

column6: An introduction to the methods, theories and topics of social epidemiology examining how macro and micro social environmental variables have an impact on disease and its distribution in society. Akron 3850: 615.

column6: Student negotiated project in specific human service setting for practitioner; program designing; research; in-service training; writing a grant proposal.

column6: Intensive pursuit of a subject matter beyond normal course coverage with the possibility of associated research. Only 3 credits count toward the doctoral degree.

column4: doctoral standing and sociology (SOC) major and special approval.
column6: Pursuit of research interests which can include the student's project and/or a faculty member's project. Only 4 credits count toward the doctoral degree.

Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required first of which will be semester in which dissertation is begun and continuing until 30 hours are completed. Akron 3850: 899.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.
